lesson_intermediate_tech_001.title: Moving Averages
lesson_intermediate_tech_001.subtitle: Understanding price trends with moving averages

screen_001.title: Moving Averages
screen_001.subtitle: Understanding price trends with moving averages

content.body:
Imagine standing on a highway overpass watching cars pass. Some moments are hectic with lots of traffic, other moments are quiet. If you tried to describe the 'average' traffic flow, you wouldn't just look at this exact second—you'd observe over the last 10 or 20 minutes to get a real sense of the trend.

Moving averages work the same way with price. Instead of reacting to every spike and dip, they smooth out the noise and show you the underlying direction. They answer one simple question: where has price been spending most of its time lately?

A moving average (MA) is simply the average price over a specific number of periods. The most common types are:

Simple Moving Average (SMA): Adds up the closing prices for X days and divides by X. Every day gets equal weight.

Exponential Moving Average (EMA): Gives more weight to recent prices. It reacts faster to new price action.

The 'moving' part means the average updates every period—as new data comes in, old data drops off. This creates a flowing line that follows price but smooths out the chaos.

points: 20-period MA: Short-term trend, used for quick reversals
50-period MA: Medium-term trend, popular with swing traders
200-period MA: Long-term trend, the 'line in the sand' for bulls vs bears
Price above MA = uptrend; price below MA = downtrend
MAs act as dynamic support and resistance levels

screen_005.title: Moving Average on a Chart
screen_005.subtitle: See how MAs smooth price action

content.caption: Price bouncing off the 50-day MA (blue line) multiple times—acting as dynamic support in an uptrend

content.body:
In late 2023, Apple stock was trending upward. The 50-day moving average sat around $175. Every time AAPL pulled back to test the 50-day MA, buyers stepped in aggressively, pushing price back up.

This happened four times over three months. Traders watching the MA recognized the pattern: the 50-day was acting as support. On the fifth test in early 2024, AAPL broke below the 50-day MA with heavy volume. The trend had changed.

The MA didn't cause the reversal—it simply reflected that sellers were now stronger than buyers. Price continued lower until it found support at the 200-day MA near $165.

points: Using MAs in choppy, sideways markets (they work best in trends)
Blindly buying every MA touch without confirming momentum
Expecting the MA to 'hold' every time—nothing works 100%
Using too many MAs at once and creating analysis paralysis
Forgetting that MAs are lagging indicators—they follow price, not predict it

content.body:
MAs fail in sideways, range-bound markets. When price isn't trending, it will cross above and below the MA repeatedly, generating false signals. You'll get whipsawed—buying high, selling low, over and over.

Another failure mode: death crosses and golden crosses (when the 50-day crosses the 200-day) often come late. By the time the crossover happens, the big move is already over. You're buying the top or selling the bottom.

The key is context. MAs work beautifully in trending markets but torture you in choppy conditions. Always assess the broader market structure first.

content.question: BTC is trading at $62,000. The 50-day MA is at $60,000 and rising. Price has tested the 50-day MA twice in the last two weeks and bounced both times. Now it's approaching the MA again with declining volume. What do you consider?
options: Buy immediately—third time's a charm, MAs always hold
Wait for a bounce with strong volume before entering
Avoid—declining volume suggests weakening support
Short it—MAs never work on Bitcoin
content.explanation: Waiting for confirmation is key. While the 50-day MA has held twice before, declining volume suggests buyers are getting weaker. Wait to see if the MA holds again with conviction (strong volume bounce) before entering. If it breaks below with volume, the trend may be shifting. Option C is also reasonable—avoiding weak setups is smart risk management.

points: MAs smooth out noise and reveal the underlying trend
Price above MA = uptrend; below = downtrend
MAs act as dynamic support/resistance in trending markets
They fail in choppy, sideways markets—context matters
Always wait for confirmation before trading MA touches

content.body:
Imagine stretching a rubber band. The further you pull it, the stronger the tension becomes. Eventually, it either snaps back or breaks.

RSI measures price momentum like a rubber band. When price rallies too hard, too fast, RSI climbs into 'overbought' territory (above 70). When price sells off too hard, too fast, RSI drops into 'oversold' territory (below 30).

Just like the rubber band, these extremes don't last forever. RSI helps you spot when momentum is stretched and likely to snap back—or break through entirely.

RSI (Relative Strength Index) is a momentum oscillator that measures the speed and magnitude of price changes. It ranges from 0 to 100.

The formula compares average gains to average losses over a set period (usually 14 days). When gains outweigh losses, RSI rises. When losses dominate, RSI falls.

Traditional interpretation:
- RSI above 70 = overbought (price may pull back)
- RSI below 30 = oversold (price may bounce)
- RSI near 50 = neutral momentum

But here's the critical part: overbought doesn't mean 'sell now,' and oversold doesn't mean 'buy now.' Context matters.

points: RSI > 70: Strong upward momentum, price may be overextended
RSI < 30: Strong downward momentum, price may be oversold
RSI 40-60: Neutral zone, no clear momentum edge
Divergence: When RSI and price move in opposite directions (powerful signal)
RSI works best when combined with trend and support/resistance

content.caption: RSI dipping below 30 (oversold) and bouncing—price follows with a rally shortly after

content.body:
In January 2024, Tesla stock was making higher highs, climbing from $240 to $260. Bulls were celebrating. But RSI was making lower highs—even as price pushed higher, momentum was weakening.

This is called bearish divergence. It warned that the rally was running out of steam. Two weeks later, TSLA reversed sharply, falling back to $220 within a month.

Conversely, in March 2024, Bitcoin made lower lows around $60,000, but RSI made higher lows. This bullish divergence signaled that selling pressure was weakening. BTC rallied to $72,000 within three weeks.

Divergences don't give you exact timing, but they do give you a warning: momentum is shifting.

points: Selling just because RSI hits 70 (strong trends stay overbought for weeks)
Buying just because RSI hits 30 (downtrends stay oversold for a long time)
Ignoring the broader trend—RSI works best with trend, not against it
Using RSI alone without price context or support/resistance
Missing divergences because you're only watching the 70/30 levels

content.body:
RSI fails in strong trending markets. In a powerful uptrend, RSI can stay above 70 for weeks or even months. If you sell every time it hits overbought, you'll miss the entire rally.

Similarly, in a strong downtrend, RSI can stay below 30 for extended periods. Buying every oversold reading will catch you falling knives.

The fix: adjust your interpretation based on trend. In an uptrend, wait for RSI to dip to 40-50 (not 30) before buying. In a downtrend, wait for RSI to rally to 50-60 (not 70) before considering shorts.

RSI is a tool, not a trade signal. It shows momentum—you provide the context.

content.question: ETH is in a strong uptrend, making higher highs. RSI has been above 70 for the past 10 days. What should you do?
options: Sell immediately—RSI is overbought, a crash is coming
Do nothing—strong trends stay overbought, wait for trend breakdown
Short it—RSI above 70 always means reversal
Buy more—overbought means it's going higher
content.explanation: In strong uptrends, RSI can stay overbought (above 70) for extended periods. Selling just because RSI is high will cause you to miss the bulk of the trend. Instead, wait for the trend structure to break (lower high, break of support) before considering an exit. Overbought in a trend is normal—it's not a sell signal by itself.

content.body:
The most powerful use of RSI isn't the 70/30 levels—it's divergence.

Bullish divergence: Price makes a lower low, but RSI makes a higher low. This shows that even though price fell further, the selling pressure is weakening. A reversal may be near.

Bearish divergence: Price makes a higher high, but RSI makes a lower high. Even though price pushed higher, momentum is fading. The rally may be running out of steam.

Divergences don't guarantee reversals, but they're early warnings. When you spot one, tighten your stops, watch for confirmation, and prepare for a potential shift.

points: RSI measures momentum, not direction—use it with trend context
Overbought (>70) doesn't mean sell; oversold (<30) doesn't mean buy
Strong trends stay overbought/oversold for extended periods
Divergences (RSI vs price) are powerful early warning signals
Always combine RSI with support/resistance and trend analysis

lesson_intermediate_tech_003.title: MACD - Moving Average Convergence Divergence
lesson_intermediate_tech_003.subtitle: Tracking momentum shifts and trend changes

screen_001.title: MACD
screen_001.subtitle: Tracking momentum shifts and trend changes

content.body:
Imagine you're driving on the highway. Your speedometer shows your current speed, but to know if you're accelerating or decelerating, you watch how fast the needle is moving.

MACD works the same way. It doesn't just tell you if price is going up or down—it tells you if momentum is accelerating or decelerating. Are buyers getting stronger? Are sellers losing steam?

This is incredibly valuable because momentum often shifts before price does. MACD helps you spot these shifts early, giving you an edge in timing entries and exits.

MACD (Moving Average Convergence Divergence) is a trend-following momentum indicator. It has three components:

1. MACD Line: The difference between the 12-period and 26-period exponential moving averages (EMAs). It shows momentum direction.

2. Signal Line: A 9-period EMA of the MACD line. It acts as a trigger for buy/sell signals.

3. Histogram: The difference between the MACD line and signal line. It visualizes momentum strength.

When the MACD line crosses above the signal line, it suggests bullish momentum. When it crosses below, it suggests bearish momentum. The histogram shows how strong that momentum is.

points: MACD above zero = bullish momentum; below zero = bearish momentum
MACD crosses above signal line = potential buy signal (bullish crossover)
MACD crosses below signal line = potential sell signal (bearish crossover)
Histogram expanding = momentum strengthening
Histogram shrinking = momentum weakening (even if trend continues)

content.caption: MACD line crossing above signal line (bullish crossover)—price rally follows shortly after

content.body:
In October 2023, the S&P 500 was in a downtrend, making lower lows. The MACD was below zero, confirming bearish momentum. But in late October, the MACD line crossed above the signal line while still below zero—an early bullish crossover.

Traders watching MACD saw this as a potential momentum shift. Two weeks later, SPY broke above resistance and began a strong rally that lasted through year-end, climbing from $420 to $475.

The crossover didn't guarantee the rally, but it warned that sellers were losing control. Combined with price breaking resistance, it was a high-probability setup.

Conversely, in July 2024, MACD crossed below the signal line near all-time highs. The histogram started shrinking. SPY chopped sideways for weeks before finally rolling over—MACD gave the early warning.

points: Taking every crossover as a trade signal (many are false in choppy markets)
Ignoring the zero line—crossovers below zero in downtrends are weaker
Not waiting for price confirmation (MACD can cross, but price may not follow)
Using MACD alone without checking support, resistance, or trend
Expecting instant results—MACD is a lagging indicator, give it time

content.body:
MACD fails in sideways, choppy markets. When price is range-bound with no clear trend, the MACD line will cross the signal line repeatedly, whipsawing you with false signals.

Another failure mode: late signals. Because MACD is based on moving averages, it lags price. By the time you get a crossover, the move may already be halfway done—or even over.

The solution: use MACD as confirmation, not initiation. Don't trade the crossover alone. Wait for price to confirm the signal by breaking support/resistance or forming a clear pattern. MACD works best when it aligns with what price is already telling you.

content.question: Bitcoin is trending down. MACD is below zero. The MACD line crosses above the signal line, but price is still below the 50-day moving average and making lower highs. What do you do?
options: Buy immediately—MACD crossover is a strong buy signal
Wait for price to break above the 50-day MA before considering a long
Ignore it—MACD crossovers below zero in downtrends are unreliable
Short it—MACD doesn't matter, trend is down
content.explanation: The MACD crossover suggests weakening bearish momentum, but price is still in a downtrend structure (below 50-day MA, lower highs). Wait for price to confirm the momentum shift by breaking above resistance or the 50-day MA. Option C is also reasonable—many crossovers in downtrends fail. Never trade MACD alone without price confirmation.

points: MACD measures momentum acceleration and deceleration
Crossovers suggest momentum shifts, not guaranteed trend changes
Histogram shows momentum strength—watch it shrink before reversals
MACD fails in choppy, sideways markets—only use in trending conditions
Always confirm MACD signals with price action and support/resistance

content.body:
Imagine watching a soccer match. When something exciting happens—a goal, a near miss—the crowd roars. When nothing is happening, the stadium is quiet.

Volume is like the crowd's reaction. High volume means lots of traders are participating—buying and selling aggressively. Low volume means apathy—few people care.

Here's the key: when price moves on high volume, it's real. When price moves on low volume, it's questionable. Volume confirms conviction. Without it, price moves are just noise.

Volume measures how many shares, contracts, or coins changed hands during a given period. It's displayed as bars at the bottom of most charts.

High volume = strong conviction. Lots of traders are participating, and the move is meaningful.

Low volume = weak conviction. Few traders are involved, and the move may not hold.

Volume doesn't tell you direction—it tells you intensity. A breakout on huge volume is far more reliable than a breakout on weak volume. A selloff on low volume may just be noise, but a selloff on massive volume signals real fear.

points: Price + high volume = strong move, likely to continue
Price + low volume = weak move, likely to reverse
Volume confirms breakouts—without it, breakouts often fail
Rising price + falling volume = divergence, rally losing steam
Falling price + rising volume = strong selling, breakdown confirmed

content.caption: Price breaking resistance with massive volume spike—confirms strong buying interest

screen_006.title: Real Market Example: NVIDIA (NVDA) Earnings Breakout

content.body:
In May 2024, NVIDIA was consolidating around $900 after a massive rally. Volume had been declining for weeks—traders were waiting.

Then earnings came. NVDA exploded higher, breaking $950 resistance on volume 5x the daily average. This wasn't a fake breakout—institutions were piling in. The stock rallied to $1,200 within a month.

Contrast this with a different scenario: in August 2024, Bitcoin broke above $62,000 resistance but volume was below average. The breakout failed within two days, and BTC fell back into the range.

The difference? Volume. NVDA had conviction behind it. Bitcoin's breakout was just noise.

points: Ignoring volume entirely and only watching price
Buying breakouts with weak volume—most fail quickly
Not noticing volume divergence (price up, volume down)
Treating all volume spikes the same—context matters (breakout vs selloff)
Forgetting that volume is relative—compare to recent average, not absolute numbers

content.body:
Volume divergence happens when price and volume move in opposite directions. It's a powerful warning signal.

Bullish divergence: Price is falling, but volume is decreasing. This suggests selling pressure is weakening. Sellers are losing conviction. A reversal may be near.

Bearish divergence: Price is rising, but volume is decreasing. This suggests buying pressure is fading. The rally is running out of steam.

In March 2024, Ethereum rallied from $3,200 to $3,800, but volume dropped every week. This bearish divergence warned that the rally was weak. ETH reversed sharply two weeks later.

Volume divergence doesn't give exact timing, but it gives context: the current move is losing support.

content.question: SPY breaks above resistance at $500 on volume that's 30% below the 20-day average. What's your assessment?
options: Strong breakout—buy immediately
Weak breakout—wait for volume confirmation or avoid
Volume doesn't matter—breakouts always work
Short it—low volume means it's going down
content.explanation: Low volume breakouts often fail because they lack conviction. Without strong participation, the move is likely driven by a few traders, not broad market belief. Wait to see if volume picks up and the breakout holds, or avoid it entirely. High-probability breakouts come with high volume.

points: Volume confirms price moves—high volume = conviction
Breakouts need volume to succeed; low-volume breakouts usually fail
Volume divergence warns of weakening trends before price reverses
Compare volume to recent average, not absolute levels
Always check volume before entering breakout or breakdown trades

lesson_intermediate_tech_005.title: Support & Resistance
lesson_intermediate_tech_005.subtitle: Finding key price levels where buyers and sellers battle

screen_001.title: Support & Resistance
screen_001.subtitle: Finding key price levels where buyers and sellers battle

content.body:
Imagine you're in a room. The floor stops you from falling through, and the ceiling stops you from floating up. You can push against them, but breaking through takes serious force.

Support and resistance work the same way in markets. Support is like a floor—a price level where buyers tend to step in and stop the decline. Resistance is like a ceiling—a level where sellers step in and stop the rally.

These levels aren't magical. They exist because traders remember past prices and act on those memories. If a stock bounced at $100 three times before, traders expect it to bounce again. Those expectations create the very support they anticipate.

Support is a price level where buying pressure historically emerges, preventing further declines. Think of it as a zone where buyers believe the asset is 'cheap' and step in.

Resistance is a price level where selling pressure historically emerges, preventing further rallies. Sellers believe the asset is 'expensive' and take profits.

These levels form from:
- Previous swing highs and lows
- Round psychological numbers ($100, $50,000)
- Moving averages
- Trendlines
- Volume clusters (where lots of trading happened)

The more times a level holds, the stronger it becomes—because more traders are watching it.

points: Support acts as a floor—price bounces when it hits support
Resistance acts as a ceiling—price reverses when it hits resistance
The more tests a level survives, the stronger it becomes
Role reversal: broken support becomes new resistance (and vice versa)
Zones, not exact lines—support/resistance are areas, not precise prices

screen_005.title: Support Holding Multiple Times
screen_005.subtitle: Price bouncing off support creates confidence

content.caption: Three successful tests of support at $40,000—each bounce reinforces the level

screen_006.title: Real Market Example: Tesla (TSLA) Role Reversal

content.body:
In mid-2023, Tesla found strong support at $240. The stock tested this level four times over three months, bouncing each time. Traders marked $240 as a key support zone.

But in September 2023, TSLA broke below $240 on heavy volume. The support had failed. What happened next?

When Tesla tried to rally back, it couldn't break above $240. The old support had become new resistance—a role reversal. Sellers who were trapped at higher prices used the bounce to exit, capping the rally.

This is a critical concept: when support breaks, it often becomes resistance. The level doesn't disappear—it just flips roles. Traders who bought at support are now underwater and eager to sell if price returns.

points: Drawing support/resistance through candle wicks instead of bodies
Buying the exact support level without waiting for confirmation
Treating all levels as equal—some are far stronger than others
Ignoring volume when levels break (high volume = real break)
Expecting levels to hold forever—nothing works 100% of the time

content.body:
Support and resistance break when the balance of power shifts. If enough sellers overwhelm buyers at support, it breaks. If enough buyers overwhelm sellers at resistance, it breaks.

Signs of a real break:
- High volume on the break (conviction)
- Strong close beyond the level (not just a spike)
- No immediate reclaim attempt
- Acceleration after the break

Fake breaks (stop hunts) happen when price briefly pierces a level, triggers stops, then reverses. This is why you wait for confirmation—a candle close beyond the level, ideally with volume.

Once a level breaks convincingly, it often becomes the opposite: broken support turns into resistance, and broken resistance turns into support.

content.question: Bitcoin is approaching resistance at $65,000 for the third time in a month. Previous tests were rejected with high volume. This time, volume is declining as it approaches. What do you consider?
options: Buy aggressively—third time it will break through
Wait for a breakout with strong volume before entering
Fade the resistance—expect rejection again
Do nothing—resistance always holds
content.explanation: Declining volume as price approaches resistance suggests weakening buying pressure. The level has held twice with strong volume, so it's a proven resistance. Wait to see if BTC breaks above with conviction (high volume, strong close) before buying. Option C (fading resistance) is also reasonable, but riskier—resistance can break at any time. Never assume levels hold forever.

content.body:
Some support and resistance levels aren't based on past price action—they're based on human psychology. Round numbers like $100, $1,000, $50,000 act as magnets.

Why? People think in round numbers. A stock at $98 'feels' close to $100. Traders set buy orders at $50 or $100, not $49.37. This clustering of orders creates real support and resistance.

Bitcoin's $60,000, $65,000, and $70,000 levels acted as strong resistance in 2024—not because of technical patterns, but because they're round numbers where profit-taking clustered.

Always mark major round numbers on your charts. They're invisible walls that often stop price in its tracks.

points: Support and resistance are zones where buying/selling pressure emerges
The more times a level holds, the stronger it becomes
Broken support becomes resistance; broken resistance becomes support
Always wait for volume confirmation when levels break
Round psychological numbers ($100, $50,000) act as strong levels

lesson_intermediate_tech_006.title: Chart Patterns
lesson_intermediate_tech_006.subtitle: Recognizing repeating setups in price action

screen_001.title: Chart Patterns
screen_001.subtitle: Recognizing repeating setups in price action

content.body:
Imagine tracking an animal through fresh snow. After a while, you start recognizing patterns. The spacing of the tracks, the depth, the direction—they tell you where the animal is going and how it's moving.

Chart patterns are the same. They're footprints left by buyer and seller behavior. When you see a familiar pattern forming, you can anticipate what's likely to happen next—not because patterns are magic, but because human psychology repeats.

Fear, greed, and uncertainty create recognizable formations in price. Once you learn to spot these patterns, you gain an edge in timing entries and exits.

Chart patterns are recognizable formations that price creates as it moves. They reflect the battle between buyers and sellers, and often signal what's coming next.

Patterns fall into two categories:

Continuation patterns: Signal the trend will continue after a pause (flags, pennants, triangles in trending markets).

Reversal patterns: Signal the trend is ending and price will reverse (double tops/bottoms, head and shoulders).

Patterns aren't guarantees—they're probabilities. A well-formed pattern in the right context increases your odds, but nothing works 100% of the time. Context matters: trend, volume, support/resistance.

points: Double Top/Bottom: Price tests same level twice, fails, reverses
Head & Shoulders: Three peaks, middle is highest—signals reversal
Triangles: Price squeezes into smaller range before breaking out
Flags & Pennants: Short consolidations in strong trends before continuation
All patterns need volume confirmation to be reliable

content.caption: Left shoulder, head, right shoulder—neckline break confirms reversal

screen_006.title: Real Market Example: S&P 500 Double Top (2022)

content.body:
In early 2022, the S&P 500 rallied to $4,800 in January, forming a peak. It pulled back, then rallied again in March to $4,630—close to the prior high but couldn't break above it.

This formed a double top: two peaks at roughly the same level with a valley in between. The pattern warned that buyers were losing strength—they couldn't push to new highs.

When SPY broke below the valley support at $4,200, the pattern confirmed. The market fell 25% over the next six months, reaching $3,600 by October.

The double top didn't predict the exact decline, but it signaled that the uptrend was exhausted. Traders watching the pattern had advance warning to tighten stops or take profits.

Not all patterns signal reversals. Flags and pennants are continuation patterns—they appear in the middle of strong trends and signal the trend will resume.

Flag: After a strong move, price consolidates in a tight, parallel channel (looks like a flag on a pole). When it breaks out, the trend continues.

Pennant: Similar to a flag, but the consolidation forms a small symmetrical triangle instead of a channel.

These patterns represent brief pauses where traders take profits or catch their breath. Once the consolidation ends, the original trend usually resumes with force.

In June 2024, Bitcoin rallied from $60,000 to $68,000 (the pole), then formed a tight flag between $67,000-$68,500 for a week. When it broke above $68,500, BTC surged to $72,000 within days.

points: Seeing patterns everywhere—only well-formed, clear patterns matter
Trading patterns without volume confirmation (most fail)
Ignoring the broader trend—patterns work best with trend context
Jumping in before the pattern completes (be patient, wait for breakout)
Treating all patterns equally—some are far more reliable than others

content.body:
Chart patterns fail when volume doesn't confirm the breakout, or when broader market conditions override the pattern.

A head and shoulders pattern might form perfectly, but if the overall market is in a raging bull trend, the pattern may fail. Context beats patterns.

Another common failure: fake breakouts. Price breaks the pattern boundary, triggers stops, then reverses back into the range. This is why you wait for a strong close beyond the pattern and ideally a retest of the breakout level.

Patterns are tools, not crystal balls. They improve your odds when combined with trend, support/resistance, and volume—but never trade them in isolation.

content.question: AAPL forms a symmetrical triangle after a strong rally. Volume has been declining during the triangle formation. Price breaks above the triangle on low volume. What's your move?
options: Buy immediately—triangle breakouts always work
Wait for volume confirmation and a retest of the breakout
Ignore it—patterns don't matter
Short it—low volume means it's going down
content.explanation: Low-volume breakouts often fail. The triangle pattern is valid, but without volume confirmation, the breakout is questionable. Wait to see if volume picks up and the breakout holds, or wait for a retest of the triangle top (now support) before entering. High-probability setups combine pattern + volume + trend.

content.body:
Patterns work best when they align with other factors—what traders call confluence.

A head and shoulders pattern at major resistance, with bearish RSI divergence, and declining volume? That's powerful confluence. Multiple factors pointing the same direction.

A bull flag forming at a key support level, with rising volume and a bullish MACD crossover? High-probability continuation setup.

Don't trade patterns alone. Stack them with:
- Support/resistance levels
- Moving averages
- Volume confirmation
- RSI or MACD signals
- Broader trend alignment

The more factors that agree, the higher your probability of success.

points: Chart patterns reflect recurring buyer/seller psychology
Reversal patterns (double tops, H&S) signal trend exhaustion
Continuation patterns (flags, pennants) signal trend will resume
Always wait for volume confirmation before trading patterns
Patterns work best when combined with trend, S/R, and momentum
